title: MIDREGs — Leadership Lab SOP (Response Procedure)
expectation: Be familiar with Sections 3-2, 5-2, and 7-2 of MIDREGs. Demonstrate proper lab response procedure. Explain proper electronic communication procedures.

CO/XO/Guests: Greeting of the day, sir/ma’am, MIDN LastName
Remain standing until they finish speaking or MIDN is told to sit

examples: MIDN X, how would you respond if the XO addresses you during lab?
MIDN X, if MSgt asks you a question during lab, how do you respond properly?
MIDN X, describe the lab response preocedure for any situation.

title: MIDREGs — Inclement Weather & PT/NWUs
expectation: Recall key facts.
excerpt: MIDN are expected to bring a full hydration source to all PT evolutions
MIDN will form up in track suits regardless of temperature
Plain dark blue/black jacket to/from PT ok (no visible brand); remove for form up
Plain black bag (no visible brand) allowed to/from PT
NWU fleece permitted as jacket to/from PT
examples: MIDN X, what must you bring to every PT evolution?
MIDN X, what type of jacket is permitted when traveling to PT?

title: MIDREGs — Electronic Communications
expectation: Recall key facts.

excerpt.Email_Primary: Clear, concise, formal; prefer POW for broad announcements.
excerpt.Addresses: Use name+rank; not class year in greeting line
excerpt.SignOffs: Include rank + class year; billet if applicable (e.g., “MIDN 1/C Jones\nBnXO”)
excerpt.Phone_Text: Use for urgency; be respectful; no prompt after-hours replies unless extreme urgency

examples: MIDN X, how should you address an email to a MIDN 1/C?
MIDN X, what should you include in your email signature block?
MIDN X, what is the proper closing when emailing a staff member?
MIDN X, how should you address an email to unit staff?

title: Chain of Command (FA25)
expectation: Know the Chain of Command verbatim
excerpt: Commander in Chief — The Honorable Donald J. Trump
Secretary of Defense — The Honorable Peter B. Hegseth
Secretary of the Navy — The Honorable John C. Phelan
Chief of Naval Operations — ADM Daryl Caudle
Commandant of the Marine Corps — Gen Eric Smith
Chief of Naval Personnel — VADM Jeffrey Czerewko
NETC — RADM Gregory Huffman
NSTC — RDML Matthew Pottenburgh
MCPON — MCPON John Perryman
SMMC — SMMC Carlos Ruiz
notes: Subject to change; MIDN must know current office holders.
examples: MIDN X, who is the Chief of Naval Personnel?
MIDN X, who is the Commandant of the Marine Corps?
MIDN X, who is the Commander in Chief.
MIDN X, who is the Chief of Naval Operations?

title: Addressing and Greeting Personnel
expectation: Be familiar with the proper address and greeting for military personnel of any rank.

Groups.EdgeCases: Address senior gender first; pause or use 'and' in writing

Officers: CO of ship/station is 'Captain' regardless of rank
Enlisted_Navy: Other petty officers: use rate or 'Petty Officer'
excerpt.Enlisted_USMC: Use full rank (e.g., 'Staff Sergeant Smith'); never shorten for E-6+.
excerpt.Formality: Use most formal form when in doubt

examples: MIDN X, how would you greet a female officer at 0800?
MIDN X, what is the proper greeting for a group of male and female officers?

title: Saluting — Custom & Exceptions
expectation: Be familiar with how to salute and when/when not to salute.
excerpt: Right hand customary; left hand allowed if right is injured/occupied
Navy/USMC: salute covered; Army/AF may salute uncovered — adapt to setting ('When in Rome…')
From attention if halted; keep erect while walking; slow from double
Upper arm parallel to deck; forearm 45°; palm slightly inward; fingers joined; forefinger to cap brim right of eye
Face/look at person; allow ~6 steps for exchange
Hold until returned/acknowledged or passed
Accompany with verbal greeting; if both hands occupied, verbal greeting only
If on cell: pause, drop phone, attention, salute
All senior officers (U.S. & allied); USMM & USPHS officers
Recognized seniors even in civilian clothes/uncovered
Medal of Honor recipients (regardless of rank/rate)
Officer of the Deck; division/detail muster lead
Walk/stand on senior’s left; salute when they do
Group: first to see calls 'Attention'; all face and salute
Passing senior: pass left, salute abeam, 'By your leave…' — 'Very well'
Crowded: salute when addressing/being addressed
Return salutes from children/retirees
When in doubt, salute
In formation (leader salutes/gives command)
Engaged in work or part of a work detail (leader salutes)
Carrying items in both hands (verbal greeting ok)
Public places where inappropriate (bus, line, etc.)
At mess (sit at attention if addressed)
Combat/simulated combat conditions
examples: MIDN X, when is it acceptable to salute with your left hand?
MIDN X, how should you adapt your saluting customs when visiting an Army base?
MIDN X, describe the proper position of the forearm and hand when saluting.
MIDN X, how should you salute when walking versus standing still?
MIDN X, what should you do if you are holding a phone when a senior officer approaches?
MIDN X, when passing a senior officer outdoors, when should you render your salute?
MIDN X, do you salute Medal of Honor recipients?
MIDN X, what should you do if you are in a group and a senior officer approaches?
MIDN X, should you salute while in formation?
MIDN X, are salutes rendered while carrying items in both hands?
MIDN X, when at mess, how should you respond if addressed by a senior officer?

title: Ranks and Insignia (USN/USMC)
expectation: Recall verbatim the corresponding rank and title when shown insignia. Properly describe insignia corresponding to a given rank or title.

Navy.Shoulder: None
None
None
None
None
None

MarineCorps.Insignia: Three chevrons above one rocker with crossed rifles

Navy.Shoulder: None

MarineCorps.Insignia: Three chevrons above two rockers with crossed rifles

Navy.Collar: Gold fouled anchor with one silver star and silver "USN"
Navy.Sleeve: Eagle + one rocker + three chevrons + one star
Navy.Shoulder: None

MarineCorps.Insignia: Three chevrons above three rockers with crossed rifles

Navy.Rank: Master Chief Petty Officer / Master Chief Petty Officer of the Navy
Navy.Collar: Gold fouled anchor with two silver stars and silver "USN"
Navy.Sleeve: Eagle + one rocker + three chevrons + two stars
Navy.Shoulder: Black shoulder board with gold fouled anchor, two silver stars, and "USN"

MarineCorps.Insignia: Three chevrons above four rockers with a star

Navy.Shoulder: Gold bar with 2 blue squares

MarineCorps.Insignia: Red bar with two gold squares

Navy.Shoulder: Gold bar with 3 blue squares

Navy.Collar: Silver bar with two blue squares
Navy.Shoulder: Silver bar with two blue squares

MarineCorps.Insignia: Silver bar with two red squares

Navy.Collar: Single silver bar with three blue squares
Navy.Shoulder: Single silver bar with three blue squares

MarineCorps.Insignia: Single silver bar with three red squares

Navy.Collar: Single silver bar with one vertical blue stripe
Navy.Shoulder: Single silver bar with one vertical blue stripe

MarineCorps.Insignia: Silver bar with one vertical red stripe

Navy.Shoulder: White background with one ½″ gold stripe

Navy.Sleeve: One ¼″ + one ½″ gold stripe
Navy.Shoulder: White background with one ¼″ + one ½″ gold stripe
White background with two ½″ gold stripes

Navy.Sleeve: One ½″ stripe with one ¼″ stripe above
Navy.Shoulder: White background with same pattern
White background with three ½″ gold stripes
White background with four ½″ gold stripes
White background with one silver star and one gold stripe

Navy.Sleeve: One 1″ gold stripe and one 1/2″ inch gold stripe
Navy.Shoulder: White background with two silver stars and one gold stripe

Navy.Sleeve: One 1″ gold stripe and two 1/2″ inch gold stripes
Navy.Shoulder: White background with three silver stars and one gold stripe

Navy.Sleeve: One 1″ gold stripe and three 1/2″ inch gold stripes
Navy.Shoulder: White background with four silver stars and one gold stripe

examples: MIDN X, what is the rank and insignia of a Navy E-7?
MIDN X, what is the collar device for a CWO2 in the Marine Corps?
MIDN X, what is the abbreviation and insignia for a Navy Petty Officer Second Class?
MIDN X, what rank is equivalent to a Navy Captain in the Marine Corps?

title: Midshipmen Ranks and Insignia
expectation: Recall verbatim the corresponding rank and title when shown insignia. Properly describe insignia corresponding to a given rank or title.

1/C.Sleeve: Three thin gold stripes on the upper arm

2/C.Sleeve: Two thin gold stripes on the upper arm

3/C.Sleeve: one thin gold stripe on the upper arm
3/C.Collar: One gold anchor on the right collar

3/C.Sleeve: one thin gold stripe on the upper arm
3/C.Collar: One gold anchor on the right collar

examples: MIDN X, identify the insignia for a MIDN Commander
MIDN X, describe the khaki collar insignia for a MIDN 3/C
MIDN X, describe the sleeve insignia for a MIDN 2/C

title: Navy Policies — Definitions
expectation: Be familiar with the definitions of hazing, discrimination, fraternization, sexual harassment, and the Navy’s approach towards them. Know the reporting options for victims of sexual assault.

excerpt.Hazing: Strenuous/humiliating tasks without training purpose (often initiation).
excerpt.Discrimination: Unjust/prejudicial treatment based on protected categories.
excerpt.Fraternization: Unduly familiar relationships without respect to rank; favoritism risk.
excerpt.SexualHarassment: Unwanted sexual advances/remarks in professional/social context.
excerpt.Policy: Zero tolerance for all of the above.

examples: MIDN X, define hazing.
MIDN X, what is the definition of fraternization?
MIDN X, what does the Navy’s policy on hazing?

title: SAPR — Definition of Sexual Assault
expectation: Be familiar with the definitions of hazing, discrimination, fraternization, sexual harassment, and the Navy’s approach towards them. Know the reporting options for victims of sexual assault.
excerpt: Intentional sexual contact with force/threat/abuse of authority or without/ incapable of consent
Includes rape, non-consensual sodomy, indecent assault, attempts
Can occur regardless of gender, spousal relationship, or age
Consent ≠ lack of resistance; not given under force, threat, coercion, sleep, incapacitation, or unconsciousness
examples: MIDN X, how does the Navy define sexual assault?

title: SAPR — Reporting Options
expectation: Be familiar with the definitions of hazing, discrimination, fraternization, sexual harassment, and the Navy’s approach towards them. Know the reporting options for victims of sexual assault.

Restricted: Confidential; no official investigation; command notified 'an assault' occurred (limited details, no name)
Victim gets medical/mental health, advocacy, legal advice
Eligible even if previously disclosed to chain of command
May report to: SARC, SAPR VA, Healthcare personnel
NAVADMIN 151/22 nuances; commanders/law enforcement reporting can still apply in certain cases
Unrestricted: Official investigation and command notification + services
Report to: Commander (contacts MCIO), Law Enforcement/MCIO, SARC, SAPR VA, Healthcare (contacts SARC)

examples: MIDN X, name two personnel you can report a restricted sexual assault to.
MIDN X, what happens when you make an unrestricted report?
MIDN X, can a restricted report be converted to an unrestricted one later?

title: Birthdates — USN & USMC
expectation: Know the birthdates of the US Navy and US Marine Corps.
excerpt: U.S. Navy — 13 October 1775
U.S. Marine Corps — 10 November 1775
examples: MIDN X, what is the birthday of the the United States Navy?
MIDN X, what is the Marine Corps’ birthday?

title: Oath of Office
expectation: Recall the Oath of Office verbatim.
excerpt: I, [name], do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office upon which I am about to enter. So help me God.
examples: MIDN X, recite the Oath of Office.

title: Oath of Enlistment
expectation: Know the Oath of Enlistment verbatim. Be able to explain the difference between the Oaths of Office and Enlistment and why it matters.
excerpt: I, [name], do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same, and that I will obey the orders of the President of the United States and the orders of the officers appointed over me, according to regulations and the Uniform Code of Military Justice. So help me God.
examples: MIDN X, recite the Oath of Enlistment.

title: Differences — Officer vs Enlistment Oaths
expectation: Be able to explain the difference between the Oaths of Office and Enlistment and why it matters.
excerpt: Both: support and defend the Constitution
Enlisted: additionally swear to obey orders of POTUS and officers per regulations/UCMJ
Officers: pledge to faithfully discharge duties of office (no 'obey orders' clause), binding them to the Constitution (safeguard vs. personal rule; responsibility/leadership focus)
examples: MIDN X, what is one major difference between the officer and enlisted oaths?

title: U.S. Navy Mission
expectation: Recall the US Navy Mission verbatim.
excerpt: The mission of the Navy is to maintain, train and equip combat-ready naval forces capable of winning wars, deterring aggression and maintaining freedom of the seas.
examples: MIDN X, what is the mission of the United States Navy, verbatim?

title: Recall the NROTC Mission verbatim.
expectation: Recall verbatim.
excerpt: To develop midshipmen mentally, morally and physically and to imbue them with the highest ideals of duty, and loyalty, and with the core values of honor, courage and commitment in order to commission college graduates as naval officers who possess a basic professional background, are motivated toward careers in the naval service, and have a potential for future development in mind and character so as to assume the highest responsibilities of command, citizenship and government.
examples: MIDN X, what is the mission of the NROTC?

title: Sailor’s Creed
expectation: Recall the Sailor’s Creed verbatim.
excerpt: I am a United States Sailor.
I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States of America and I will obey the orders of those appointed over me.
I represent the fighting spirit of the Navy and those who have gone before me to defend freedom and democracy around the world.
I proudly serve my country's Navy combat team with honor, courage and commitment.
I am committed to excellence and the fair treatment of all.
examples: MIDN X, recite the Sailor’s Creed.

title: NROTC Course Requirements — Naval Science
expectation: Be familiar with the required Naval Science courses and college class requirements applicable to you specifically.
examples: MIDN X, what Naval Science courses must a 4/C take?
MIDN X, list 3 naval science classes al MIDN are required to take?

title: NROTC Course Requirements — Specified (by Option)
expectation: Recall key facts.

Course_Descriptions_Short: Calculus: through single-variable diff+int; higher math can satisfy when placed out
English: grammar/composition with significant writing; PNS approved
Am Hist/NatSec: US/world military history or US National Security policy; PNS approved
World Culture/Regional: culture-focused regions of interest (per NSTCINST 1550.1); language-only not sufficient; PNS approved

examples: MIDN X, how many credits of Calculus are required for Navy Options?

title: Grooming Standards
expectation: Be familiar with grooming standards for both males and females. Know the hair regulations for both males and females.
excerpt: See NAVPERS 15665I, Article 2201 — Personal Appearance
Pay special attention to hair standards
examples: MIDN X, what are the navy hair regulations for males?

title: Proper Uniform Wear
expectation: Demonstrate proper wear of the Service Khaki, Service Dress Blue, and Appropriate Civilian Attire (ACA). Know what constitutes ACAs for both males and females.

ACAs_Examples.Male: Closed-toe shoes; slacks/khakis; collared shirt tucked with belt; no shorts (except BBQ/authorized); no rips/holes/excessively wrinkled
ACAs_Examples.Female: Same as male; sandals with heel strap permitted

examples: MIDN X, what constitues proper ACAs?

title: Billet Descriptions and Information
expectation: Demonstrate familiarity with the Boston NROTC Task Organization. Know what each of the members of Battalion and Company Staff do and which midshipmen fill those roles this semester.
examples: MIDN X, what are the primary duties of the Battalion Executive Officer?
MIDN X, who manages the PQS and oversees 4/C training?
MIDN X, what are the responsibilities of the Company Fitness Leader?
